What about this game? Why someone like me loves it? TBH I am the type of person who is EXTREMELY PICKY when it comes to Deck Card building games!! Meaning games like Magic the Gathering, I can't get into it yet but surprisingly I can get into a game like Metal Gear Acid... WTF?! Yea I know! Inscryption for me legit game me that feeling I missed when I played Metal Gear Acid! 

Here's why, the story is rich! 
The visuals are stunning. 
It's deck building mechanic is drugs!
The entire atmosphere of the game is dark tone (horror).

There's something that first that did disappointed me about this game when I first started playing and that is the game DOES NOT EXPLAIN all the game rules all at once! And some rules of the game are hidden never spoken and encourages you to figure it out. I had a hard time grasping this because I KEPT ON DYING! But then when you learn something new from your past mistakes you be like "OH MY GOD!! THIS IS ALL INTENTIONAL!!" It's genius! But at the same time it is painful. 

The game legit does an excellent job in forcing you to learn from your past mistakes so that you can make better choices the next time. Personally I love this! Cause nothing is perfect. Not everything needed to be spoon fed you. If you figured it out from the first get go you'll be fine you won't be harmed. But if you didn't you die and learn from it. AND I LOVE THAT!! CAUSE YOU GET TO USE YOUR BRAINS!! AND IT FEELS GOOD!!!!

That said, if you're like me and you're a bit iffy when it comes to deck card building games like Magic the Gathering or Yugioh and you be like "I'm not into those games." --- Then give this game a try mainly because while it is a deck card building game, it is very unique and it becomes an addiction fast.

Pro`s: 
 - Innovative mechanics.
 - Very well implemented rogue like elements.
 - Story telling and subtle jokes. Cards like "Pack Rat" card (aka. the Rat Pack band from the 50`), "Frank & Stein", etc. are cute to see :).
 - Evolving rules.
 - Constantly changes and keeps fresh
 - Endless mode.

Cons: 
 - Learning curve pretty steep. Could have done a better job explaining some things or improve UI info (on the adventure map, for example); I found myself going on the web for some additional info. Good news is that there are a lot of places where you can find info and there is a complete Wiki page out there.

 - I hope for some updating graphics and animations for Inscryption 2 :D.

negative.review:
I guess I don't know what I got out of playing this.

The gameplay itself is based around a simple four lane trading card game that gets a little thin after a while. Aside from a few mechanics it's pretty straightforward. They seem really proud of this gameplay because you are playing it constantly.

There are puzzles but they range from so easy I don't know why this should be a bar to progress to wow I actually had to look around for the solution to this one. 

The story is basically just a creepypasta/SCP. It's digestible enough but a lot of the elements (the number and types of scrybes for instance) seem arbitrary. I don't really know why this story needed to be told. It doesn't seem to come from a place of burning inspiration. The ending is incredibly abrupt and stupid. Expect a lot of fourth wall breaks and acknowledgement of ludological dissonance. Kudos for risking it by making live action segments tho more games should do that.

I guess I don't get what I was supposed to take from this. There are some really sick boss fights with some great designs. The vibe for the front half of the game is pretty great it just kind of degenerates.

Overall I'd give it a 6 out of 10. Better than average, but not worth the ten hours or so it takes to beat.

Not really a recommend from me. The game plays fine, and the gameplay loop is okay, but the way the story is told and the way the acts turn out is a bit disappointing. Act I is great, loved every second. Act II came around and I kinda felt like I was tricked, the gameplay is quite different from Act I and I wasn't a fan. I trudged through it, kinda paying attention to the story but also kind of not, because I was just wanting this part to be done with. Act III came around, and the gameplay was similar to Act I, except it used a different style map where you didn't have your path laid out in front of you, you have to go back and forth between different areas like in Act II.

Overall, the core gameplay was enjoyable enough, but I felt like the game had an identity crisis and tried being too many different things at once. If  the gameplay stayed like it was in Act I, it would be a huge recommend for me, but  since I've just finished the first boss on Act III seven hours in (half of which I was just going through the motions) and I don't feel like completing the game, or seeing the conclusion of the story, I can't say I recommend this game. Especially not when all of the screenshots and videos on the store page are from Act I - to me, it really feels like a bait-n-switch.

I hate to give a negative review to this game, it was very fun while I played, Its a sort of pseudo-roguelike card battler with a dark sense of humour, many secrets and interesting graphics, with a unique story. As you play, the game evolves and although it's not too deep at the beginning it gets to a good place in complexity. Unlike a regilar roguelike the further you progress the more different the game becomes, and this a good thing. So, the tutorial takes about 3 hours.  All of the screenshots are from the tutorial.  Once you beat it, it forces you to play an *ENTIRELY* different game that *REALLY* sucks.  I mean it's really awful.  Graphics are total garbage, gameplay is awful, etc.  AND you can't play the FUN game without unlocking a hidden feature.

Edit: After playing Kaycee's mod for about a dozen runs, and repeatedly coming across impossible to win fights, where the enemy lays 3 creatures first turn, then 3 more turn two, with no way of fixing broken  (impossible to win) fights, I'm changing my review to negative.

Why negative:
Tutorial is only 3 hours long, but it's a blast.  So there's that.  The problem is that's not enough to justify the price tag, even on sale.  There's no way to play "non-tutorial" mode on a reasonable difficulty.  I don't even mind losing to "hard" fights that "IF" I had the right cards/items I could win.  It's the "Utterly impossible no matter what cards/items" fights that are a turn off.

This is a good game with a lot of heart and passion into it. The problem: it decides it doesn't want to be a traditional card game, but rather try and tell a reddit-tier story and betray its solid art and atmosphere in the first part. The latter parts felt not as nearly as polished and thought through mechanically and felt uninspired to me aesthetically. You either like it or ya don't.

Unfortunately, I'm gonna have to go with a "do not necesarily recommend" on this one. Very much the Family Guy joke about The Godfather "insisting upon itself" -- this game does exactly that. Folks seem so convinced of its genius, but I found the "twists" and "turns" to be insufferable, the meta-textual nature of it boring and more than a little tryhard, and despite truly enjoying much of the core gameplay loops of Act I and Act II, Act III and the "ending" require researching an ARG to fully get there. Even then, the juice is not worth the squeeze! There's a lot of promise here, I thought my time with this game was going a different way for most of it, but... man, I just cannot get past how wack it ended up being. Even if it started SO STRONG. Also, I have no idea what people in other reviews are talking about with 'endlessly replayable" because mf no it is absolutely not lmao

The story is basically just a creepypasta/SCP. It's digestible enough but a lot of the elements (the number and types of scrybes for instance) seem arbitrary. I don't really know why this story needed to be told. It doesn't seem to come from a place of burning inspiration. The ending is incredibly abrupt and stupid. Expect a lot of fourth wall breaks and acknowledgement of ludological dissonance. Kudos for risking it by making live action segments tho more games should do that.

I guess I don't get what I was supposed to take from this. There are some really sick boss fights with some great designs. The vibe for the front half of the game is pretty great it just kind of degenerates.

I trudged through it, kinda paying attention to the story but also kind of not, because I was just wanting this part to be done with. Act III came around, and the gameplay was similar to Act I, except it used a different style map where you didn't have your path laid out in front of you, you have to go back and forth between different areas like in Act II.

Overall, the core gameplay was enjoyable enough, but I felt like the game had an identity crisis and tried being too many different things at once. If  the gameplay stayed like it was in Act I, it would be a huge recommend for me, but  since I've just finished the first boss on Act III seven hours in (half of which I was just going through the motions) and I don't feel like completing the game, or seeing the conclusion of the story, I can't say I recommend this game. Especially not when all of the screenshots and videos on the store page are from Act I - to me, it really feels like a bait-n-switch.

So, the tutorial takes about 3 hours.  All of the screenshots are from the tutorial.  Once you beat it, it forces you to play an *ENTIRELY* different game that *REALLY* sucks.  I mean it's really awful.  Graphics are total garbage, gameplay is awful, etc.  AND you can't play the FUN game without unlocking a hidden feature.

To play the fun game shown in screenshots after beating the game, go to start menu, hold shift, press K M.  This unlocks "Kaycee's mod", which SHOULD NOT be hidden.

Edit: After playing Kaycee's mod for about a dozen runs, and repeatedly coming across impossible to win fights, where the enemy lays 3 creatures first turn, then 3 more turn two, with no way of fixing broken  (impossible to win) fights, I'm changing my review to negative.

Why negative:
Tutorial is only 3 hours long, but it's a blast.  So there's that.  The problem is that's not enough to justify the price tag, even on sale.  There's no way to play "non-tutorial" mode on a reasonable difficulty.  I don't even mind losing to "hard" fights that "IF" I had the right cards/items I could win.  It's the "Utterly impossible no matter what cards/items" fights that are a turn off.
After the tutorial is an *entirely* different game with the worst 2D graphics I've ever seen.  It's *NOT* the same game.  It's a total bait and switch.  And Kaycee's mod doesn't make up for the ultra short "fun" part.
